learning_outcomes.description: Describe and advocate for the role of speech pathology within mental health and justice. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.1, 1.2, 1.4, 1.6, 1.7, 2.2, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1)
Explain the importance of therapeutic relationship when providing speech pathology services in the mental health and justice setting. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.1, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 2.1, 2.6, 3.1)
Describe the key characteristics of major mental health and neurodevelopmental diagnoses across the lifespan. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.3, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3)

Formulate person- and family-centred management plans to address social, emotional, behavioural, educational and occupational goals for people with communication and swallowing difficulties in the mental health and justice setting. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.1-1.7, 2,5, 3.4)
Advocate for interprofessional practice in managing people with communication and swallowing difficulties in the mental health and justice setting. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.4, 1.5, 1.7, 2.5, 2.6)
Reflect on your professional support and supervision needs to work within your scope of practice in the mental health and justice setting. (SPA PS Domains/Standards PS 2.1-2.5)

assessments.assessment_title: Managing my mental wellbeing reflection task
assessments.task_description:
Students will submit a video diary or written reflection on what they currently do to manage their own mental wellbeing, and actions they can take to ensure they are implementing sustainable strategies as they progress with their career. A detailed task description will be uploaded to the SPCH3212 Blackboard site.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
This in-semester exam assesses content taught in weeks 1-6, relating to the role of the speech pathologist in the management of children, adolescents and adults with communication and swallowing disorders within mental health and justice settings. It will also assess content related to mental health conditions and importance of interprofessional practice. The exam will encompass short answer questions, including case-based questions. This exam will be delivered in Inspera Assessment and will be completed on your personal laptop on campus.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
In this assignment, students will be introduced to a young person in the justice system with mental health needs. Students will be provided with initial assessment data and asked to develop an easy English assessment report, goal plan, management plan, and session plan. Students will video-record themselves delivering the report and plan to their client. The assignment must be supported by evidence from research literature and show knowledge of the youth justice and mental health context. A detailed task description will be uploaded to the SPCH3212 Blackboard site.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Foundation Lectures

Two lectures will be held in weeks 1 and 13. The first lecture will provide students with understanding of important concepts and principles relevant to speech pathology practice in mental health and justice contexts. The final lecture will bring together content taught throughout the semester and discuss the future of speech pathology in mental health and justice. Both lectures will be delivered on campus. It is highly recommended that students view both lectures. Lecture recordings will be made available.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 12(28 Jul - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Online self-direted learning

These self-paced modules will further unpack the role of speech pathologists within child, adolescent, and adult mental health and justice systems. Through case examples and applied learning, students will explore the importance of therapeutic relationships, and describe major mental health and neurodevelopmental diagnoses across the lifespan. The series also emphasises interprofessional collaboration, advocacy, and the importance of professional support and supervision to work safely and effectively within scope of practice in these complex settings. Students are required to complete online learning activities prior to attendance and participation in the weekly tutorials.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 12(04 Aug - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Weekly on-campus tutorials

The tutorials will be conducted from weeks 2-12 of semester and will incorporate inquiry-based learning and small group discussion to further explore and apply principles learned in the online modules. Tutorials have been designed for experiential learning and therefore, students are expected to attend and participate in all tutorials. It is essential that students prepare for weekly tutorials by completing the online learning modules and associated preparation activities. As students will be working in small groups during this learning activity, tutorials will not be recorded.
